Recommendations for Formal Assessment
In a clinic or setting setting in which holistic care is the primary approach, a holistic clinical interview aims to understand the individual as a whole, considering comprehensively in depth their psychological symptoms, physical health, social environment, cultural background, and spiritual beliefs. Holistic approaches utilize the biopsychosocial model of care and an intersectional lens more heavily than a functional interview, which will be discussed below. For example, if an older adult, first-generation immigrant female patient arrives at the clinic with sleep concerns, the clinician will assess in great length their behaviors, lifestyle, identity, trauma, immigration journey, and medical and mental health history, in conjunction with assessment of their sleep concerns and habits. Treatment goals are eventually established, with all relevant history and information gathered in mind.20.1Table 20.1 an an

Treatment interventions/procedures
Outline treatment idea/procedure based on the problem and also provide the patient with a small intervention duringthissession (i. e., small homework assignment, coping skill) and measurement-based care
For example, in primary primary care outpatient settings, a patient who is an older adult male may express interest in working on one specific problem, such as diminished energy. For example, the psychologist can help patients identify that sleep is an actionable target problem for diminished energy. The psychologist can introduce a short course of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) . During the intake, the clinician may find that the patient has misconceived ideas about sleep and aging, such that older adults sleep less and nap more. Functionally, the clinician can underscore this as a misperception right away as their initial intake intervention and then introduce CBT-I as the mode of therapy (see Table 20.2 ). An additional example is a patient who presents at the referral of their primary care doctor for stress related to chronic pain may ultimately be introduced to CBT for Chronic Pain (CBT-CP) by the end of the interview and requested to complete an assignment before the next session that relates to to the treatment.
